Label: abaca fibre
Scope note: Musa textilis from the Musaceae family. Manila hemp is not to be confused with true hemp from Cannabis sativa.

Label: abrus seed
Scope note: Abrus precatorius

Label: acacia fibre
Scope note: Species of the Acacia genus belong to the subfamily Mimosoideae of the Fabaceae family (formerly known as the Leguminosae). The genus Acacia is currently undergoing taxonomic re-evaluation (following cladistic analyses) and it is likely that in the future the term Acacia will only be applicable to Acacia species in Australia, not in the rest of the world such as in Africa, the Near East, southern Asia and the Americas. This information will be updated when the new list is published.

Label: acacia nilotica flower
Scope note: Species of the Acacia genus belong to the subfamily Mimosoideae of the Fabaceae family (formerly known as the Leguminosae). The genus Acacia is currently undergoing taxonomic re-evaluation (following cladistic analyses) and it is likely that in the future the term Acacia will only be applicable to Acacia species in Australia, not in the rest of the world such as in Africa, the Near East, southern Asia and the Americas. This information will be updated when the new list is published.

Label: acacia seed
Scope note: Species of the Acacia genus belong to the subfamily Mimosoideae of the Fabaceae family (formerly known as the Leguminosae). The genus Acacia is currently undergoing taxonomic re-evaluation (following cladistic analyses) and it is likely that in the future the term Acacia will only be applicable to Acacia species in Australia, not in the rest of the world such as in Africa, the Near East, southern Asia and the Americas. This information will be updated when the new list is published.

Label: acacia wood
Scope note: Species of the Acacia genus belong to the subfamily Mimosoideae of the Fabaceae family (formerly known as the Leguminosae). The genus Acacia is currently undergoing taxonomic re-evaluation (following cladistic analyses) and it is likely that in the future the term Acacia will only be applicable to Acacia species in Australia, not in the rest of the world such as in Africa, the Near East, southern Asia and the Americas. This information will be updated when the new list is published.

Label: aconite
Scope note: Species in the Aconitum genus belong to the family Ranunculaceae.

Label: acorn
Scope note: The acorn is the fruit in the form of a nut of the oak tree from the genus Quercus in the Fagaceae family.

Label: acrylic yarn
Scope note: Acrylic yarn is a thread now commonly used instead of wool for knitting, embroidery and decorative weaving.

Label: acuyuru palm leaf
Scope note: Arecaceae family.

Label: african rosewood
Scope note: Guibou in the subfamily Caesalpinioideae of the family Fabaceae (syn. Leguminosae). Former botanical synomyms include: Copaifera coleosperma Benth., Copaiva coleosperma (Benth.) Kuntze, Copaifera hymenaeifolia (Moric.) J. Leon

Label: afzelia seed
Scope note: Afzelia is a genus in the subfamily Caesalpinioideae of the family Fabaceae (syn. Leguminosae).

Label: afzelia wood
Scope note: Afzelia is a genus in the subfamily Caesalpinioideae of the family Fabaceae (syn. Leguminosae).

Label: agave
Scope note: Agave is a genus belonging in the Agavaceae family. It is not related to the Aloe genus which belongs to a different family, the Aloeaceae.

Label: agave fibre
Scope note: Agave is a genus belonging in the Agavaceae family. It is not related to the Aloe genus which belongs to a different family, the Aloeaceae.

Label: aggregate
Scope note: In this thesaurus, the term refers to man-made aggregates rather than natural ones. See also BRECCIA and CONGLOMERATE.

Label: alabaster
Scope note: Alabaster is calcium sulphate, but the word 'alabaster' in Egyptian, Near Eastern and Greek archaeology has been commonly misused for objects which in fact are made of calcite (calcium carbonate). Thus when searching for alabaster objects, users are recommended to search for Material 'calcite' as well as 'alabaster'. N.B. The suggestion by some authorities to use the term 'travertine' for Egyptian alabaster (ie. calcite) is not generally accepted.

Label: albatross feather
Scope note: Albatross, Dioamedea epomophora, feather.

Label: alder bark
Scope note: The genus Alnus belongs in the Betulaceae family. Species of alder, Alnus spp., will vary depending on their geographical distribution e.g. in Europe, North America or temperate Asia.

Label: alder leaf
Scope note: The genus Alnus belongs in the Betulaceae family. Species of alder, Alnus spp., will vary depending on their geographical distribution e.g. in Europe, North America or temperate Asia.

Label: alder root
Scope note: The genus Alnus belongs in the Betulaceae family. Species of alder, Alnus spp., will vary depending on their geographical distribution e.g. in Europe, North America or temperate Asia.

Label: alder wood
Scope note: The genus Alnus belongs in the Betulaceae family. Species of alder, Alnus spp., will vary depending on their geographical distribution e.g. in Europe, North America or temperate Asia.

Label: alfalfa fibre
Scope note: Medicago sativa L. belongs to the Fabaceae family (formerly known as Leguminosae).

Label: algaroba bean
Scope note: Species of the Prosopis genus belong to the subfamily Mimosoideae of the Fabaceae family (formerly known as Leguminosae).

Label: algaroba wood
Scope note: Species of the Prosopis genus belong to the subfamily Mimosoideae of the Fabaceae family (formerly known as Leguminosae).

Label: almond
Scope note: The term refers to the nut. Prunus dulcis, syn. Prunus amygdalus Batsch., Amygdalus communis L., Amygdalus dulcis Mill. The genus Prunus belongs to Rosaceae family.

Label: aloe
Scope note: Aloe is a genus belonging in the Aloeaceae family. It is not related to the Agave genus which belongs to a different family, the Agavaceae.

Label: aloe fibre
Scope note: Aloe is a genus belonging in the Aloeaceae family. It is not related to the Agave genus which belongs to a different family, the Agavaceae.

Label: aloe leaf
Scope note: Aloe is a genus belonging in the Aloeaceae family. It is not related to the Agave genus which belongs to a different family, the Agavaceae.

Label: aloe pith
Scope note: Aloe is a genus belonging in the Aloeaceae family. It is not related to the Agave genus which belongs to a different family, the Agavaceae.

Label: aloe wood
Scope note: Aloe is a genus belonging in the Aloeaceae family. It is not related to the Agave genus which belongs to a different family, the Agavaceae.

Label: ambatch wood
Scope note: Aeschynomene elaphroxylon Taub. (synonym Herminiera elaphroxylon Guill. & Perr.) belongs to the Fabaceae family (formerly known as the Leguminosae). Subfamily Papilionoideae

Label: amboyna wood
Scope note: Pterocarpus indicus Willd. belongs to the Fabaceae family (formerly known as the Leguminosae).

Label: american aloe
Scope note: Agave americana L belongs to the Agavaceae family. It is not related to the Aloe genus which belongs to a different family, the Aloeaceae.

Label: american aloe fibre
Scope note: Agave americana L belongs to the Agavaceae family. It is not related to the Aloe genus which belongs to a different family, the Aloeaceae

Label: american red oak
Scope note: Fagaceae family. Quercus rubra - Syn.: Quercus borealis Michx. f. var. maxima (Marsh.) Ashe, Quercus maxima (Marsh.) Ashe, Quercus falcata Michx.

Label: amrud wood
Scope note: Myrtaceae family.

Label: animal product
Scope note: The term is defined as material produced by the animal, not an integral part of the animal.

Label: animal tissue
Scope note: This term and its Narrow Terms are for combinations of constitutents (which would be too numerous to enter individually) such as 'leg', or for the whole animal, or for unspecified matter from a named animal. It is not intended to reflect 'tissue' in a strict biological sense.

Label: annatto seed
Scope note: Bixaceae family. Common names for the tree include achiote, anato, annatto, arnato, bija, bijol, bixa, lipstick tree, roucou

Label: apatite
Scope note: calcium phosphate hydroxide

Label: apple
Scope note: Rosaceae family.

Label: apple wood
Scope note: Rosaceae family.

Label: areca palm fibre
Scope note: Areca is a genus of about 50 species of single-stemmed palms in the family Arecaceae, found in humid tropical forests e.g. Areca catechu, the areca nut palm. Special note: It should not be confused with Chrysalidocarpus lutescens, syn. Dypsis lutescens (golden cane palm, or yellow butterfly palm) from the Arecaceae family which is often referred to as the 'areca palm' although it is not in that genus.

Label: areca palm fruit
Scope note: Areca is a genus of about 50 species of single-stemmed palms in the family Arecaceae, found in humid tropical forests e.g. Areca catechu, the areca nut palm. Special note: It should not be confused with Chrysalidocarpus lutescens, syn. Dypsis lutescens (golden cane palm, or yellow butterfly palm) from the Arecaceae family which is often referred to as the 'areca palm' although it is not in that genus.

Label: areca palm leaf
Scope note: Areca is a genus of about 50 species of single-stemmed palms in the family Arecaceae, found in humid tropical forests e.g. Areca catechu, the areca nut palm. Special note: It should not be confused with Chrysalidocarpus lutescens, syn. Dypsis lutescens (golden cane palm, or yellow butterfly palm) from the Arecaceae family which is often referred to as the 'areca palm' although it is not in that genus.

Label: areca palm nut
Scope note: Areca is a genus of about 50 species of single-stemmed palms in the family Arecaceae, found in humid tropical forests e.g. Areca catechu, the areca nut palm. Special note: It should not be confused with Chrysalidocarpus lutescens, syn. Dypsis lutescens (golden cane palm, or yellow butterfly palm) from the Arecaceae family which is often referred to as the 'areca palm' although it is not in that genus.

Label: areca palm spathe
Scope note: Areca is a genus of about 50 species of single-stemmed palms in the family Arecaceae, found in humid tropical forests e.g. Areca catechu, the areca nut palm. Special note: It should not be confused with Chrysalidocarpus lutescens, syn. Dypsis lutescens (golden cane palm, or yellow butterfly palm) from the Arecaceae family which is often referred to as the 'areca palm' although it is not in that genus.

Label: areca palm wood
Scope note: Areca is a genus of about 50 species of single-stemmed palms in the family Arecaceae, found in humid tropical forests e.g. Areca catechu, the areca nut palm. Special note: It should not be confused with Chrysalidocarpus lutescens, syn. Dypsis lutescens (golden cane palm, or yellow butterfly palm) from the Arecaceae family which is often referred to as the 'areca palm' although it is not in that genus.

Label: argan wood
Scope note: Argania spinosa (L.) Skeels (formerly Sideroxylon spinosum); Sapotaceae family. Uses: leaves etc for food & fodder; wood for fuelwood and charcoal; trees used for erosion control.

Label: argun palm fruit
Scope note: Medemia argun (C.Mart.)Württemb. Arecaceae family. Uses: FOOD(Infructescences); MATERIALS(Fibres, Wood).

Label: argun palm nut
Scope note: Medemia argun (C.Mart.)Württemb. Arecaceae family. Uses: FOOD(Infructescences); MATERIALS(Fibres, Wood).

Label: arrowroot leaf
Scope note: Maranta arundinacea is from the Marantaceae family. The 'term 'arrowroot' is used for other plants too, so the type of arrowroot and its context must be taken into account when choosing the correct scientific terms. For example: Zamia pumila L. (Zamiaceae family), Florida arrowroot, produces a commercial starch. The term 'arrowroot' is sometimes used in more generalised way today to describe any starch, including that from tapoica and from kudzu flour which derives from Pueraria lobata (Fabaceae family). Canna indica L. / Canna edulis (Cannaceae family) also yields "arrowroot". In addition, the term may be even more general and largely non-botanical i.e. a root used for arrows.

Label: arrowroot stem
Scope note: Maranta arundinacea is from the Marantaceae family. The 'term 'arrowroot' is used for other plants too, so the type of arrowroot and its context must be taken into account when choosing the correct scientific terms. For example: Zamia pumila L. (Zamiaceae family), Florida arrowroot, produces a commercial starch. The term 'arrowroot' is sometimes used in more generalised way today to describe any starch, including that from tapoica and from kudzu flour which derives from Pueraria lobata (Fabaceae family). Canna indica L. / Canna edulis (Cannaceae family) also yields "arrowroot". In addition, the term may be even more general and largely non-botanical i.e. a root used for arrows.

Label: arum leaf
Scope note: Arum species, i.e. arums are in the Araceae family. There are other genera in this family which are called arum lily e.g. Zantedeschia spp.

Label: ash tree bark
Scope note: Oleaceae family

Label: ash wood
Scope note: Oleaceae family.

Label: atacamite
Scope note: copper chloride hydroxide

Label: attar
Scope note: Rosa damascena Mill., and Rosa centifolia L. are from the Rosaceae family.

Label: awarra leaf
Scope note: Astrocaryum vulgare Mart. belongs to the Arecaceae family.

Label: azurite
Scope note: Cu3(CO3)2(OH)2, Copper Carbonate Hydroxide This is an intense blue colour.

Label: babiche
Scope note: Rawhide strips used in hunting bags, for example.

Label: baleen
Scope note: See also IVORY - although not the same material as baleen or whalebone, the terms have not always been applied correctly.

Label: bamboo
Scope note: Bamboos belong to the grass family Poaceae, subfamily Bambusoideae, tribe Bambuseae.

Label: banana fibre
Scope note: The term is used generically to cover fibre from both ito-basho ("thread banana") plants, the true Japanese Fibre Banana - Musa balbisiana (synonym Musa liukiuensis) and fibre from the edible banana species (Musa basjoo). Bashofu is the Japanese name of the banana fibre cloth.

Label: bark
Scope note: Barkcloth (bark cloth) is beaten or felted bark. If the name of the specific bark is known, the specific term (e.g. acacia bark) is entered. The Object Name barkcloth should be only be entered if the object is a piece of barkcloth with no known use, e.g. a sample. If the object is, e.g. an apron, that term is the Object Name. The term barkcloth is always recorded in the Description.

Label: bark fibre
Scope note: This is not a recognised scientific term.

Label: bast
Scope note: The term refers to bast fibre.

Label: bejuco
Scope note: Spanish term for thin-stemmed plants such as rattan, and for a particular twining shrub.

Label: belele salt
Scope note: Family: Amaranthaceae.

Label: bilian wood
Scope note: A Bornean timber.

Label: billon
Scope note: The term refers to a coinage metal consisting essentially of silver and copper, with silver typically in the range 10-30%. For Greek and Roman coins historically referred to as billon or base silver, enter 'base silver' in Description, 'silver' in Materials and 'base' in Materials Comment. 'Billon' is particularly associated with the coinage of medieval and early modern Europe, where it formed a recognised third level of currency, alongside gold and fine silver, used for low denominations. It is also known as 'black money' and 'base-silver'. From the 16th century it came to be replaced by copper coinage, but did not disappear completely until the 19th century.

Label: bird egg
Scope note: Use for the whole egg, or the contents of the shell; for the eggshell, enter BIRD EGGSHELL.

Label: blackbird feather
Scope note: Turdus merula merula (merle) feather

Label: bo tree leaf
Scope note: Leaf from the Scared Bo (bodhi) tree.

Label: bone
Scope note: The form of the bone, eg: 'skull', 'femur', etc. should be entered in the Description field.

Label: borax
Scope note: Borax a natural mineral (sodium borate) which, when mixed with water, is used as a flux by metalsmiths to facilitate the soldering together of jewellery components.

Label: brass
Scope note: The term copper alloy should be searched for full retrievals on objects made or bronze or brass. This is because bronze and brass have at times been used interchangeably in the old documentation, and copper alloy is the Broad Term of both. In addition, the public may refer to certain collections by their popular name, such as 'The Benin Bronzes' most of which are actually made of brass.

Label: breadfruit
Scope note: The term refers to the fruit.

Label: bronze
Scope note: The term copper alloy should be searched for full retrievals on objects made or bronze or brass. This is because bronze and brass have at times been used interchangeably in the old documentation, and copper alloy is the Broad Term of both. In addition, the public may refer to certain collections by their popular name, such as 'The Benin Bronzes' most of which are actually made of brass.

Label: buffalo horn
Scope note: The term may also have been used, incorrectly, for the AMERICAN BISON HORN; seach under both terms.

Label: buffalo skin
Scope note: See also records with BISON SKIN.

Label: buffalo tissue
Scope note: Terms referring to Buffalo may have been used incorrectly for the American Bison.

Label: calcite
Scope note: This term is taken to include the banded variety of stone alternatively known as 'Egyptian alabaster' or 'calcite-alabaster', a crystalline form of calcium carbonate. The suggestion by some authorities to use the term 'travertine' for Egyptian alabaster (ie. calcite) is not generally accepted. 'Spar' is an archaic term referring to a well-formed, generally transparent or translucent crystal referring to either feldspar, fluorspar, or dog-tooth spar (ie. calcite).

Label: camelid wool
Scope note: The term refers to South American textiles made of alpaca wool, llama wool or vicuna wool. If the precise nature of the wool has been identified, the specific term is entered, e.g. 'alpaca wool'. If there is doubt, the term is entered as. e.g. 'alpaca wool' and qualified with a '?' in the Comment field. If all that is known is 'camelid wool', that term is entered.

Label: carajuru
Scope note: The product of Bignonia chica.

Label: carapace
Scope note: The term denotes a shield of exoskeleton covering part of the body of certain animals. See also SHELL.

Label: carbon fibre
Scope note: Carbon fibre has a complex composition and can be used and adapted in many ways e.g. as loose/woven carbon filaments with many different weave patterns, or combined with a plastic resin and wound / moulded to form composite materials such as carbon fibre reinforced plastic (also referenced as carbon fibre) to provide a high strength-to-weight ratio material (C.R. Cartwright, 06/04/09).

Label: cat bone
Scope note: 'Cat' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild cats and the 'great cats' as well as domesticated varieties.

Label: cat fur
Scope note: 'Cat' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild cats and the 'great cats' as well as domesticated varieties.

Label: cat skin
Scope note: 'Cat' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild cats and the 'great cats' as well as domesticated varieties.

Label: cat tissue
Scope note: 'Cat' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild cats and the 'great cats' as well as domesticated varieties.

Label: cat tooth
Scope note: 'Cat' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild cats and the 'great cats' as well as domesticated varieties.

Label: cedrela wood
Scope note: Most commonly Cedrela odorata. Not a true cedar.

Label: cellulose nitrate
Scope note: The term 'celluloid' may have been used erroneously in old forms of documentation. The term refers specifically to cellulose nitrate. In some records where 'celluloid' was recorded in the original Description, the term entered in Material is the higher-level term (Broad Term) 'plastic'.

Label: chalcocite
Scope note: copper glance Cu2S

Label: chloritite
Scope note: Belongs to the hydroxy magnesium silicate group of minerals which inludes serpentine, soapstone (talc) and steatite.

Label: chrysoberyl
Scope note: The term chrysolite has also been used to refer to yellow chrysoberyl (and other yellow stones). It is sometimes also used to refer to gem quality olivine (which is known also as peridot).

Label: chrysolite
Scope note: The term chrysolite has also been used to refer to yellow chrysoberyl (and other yellow stones). It is sometimes also used to refer to gem quality olivine (which is known also as peridot).

Label: clay
Scope note: In this thesaurus, the term 'clay' refers to the raw material. If deliberately heated, whether in a fire or a kiln, etc. but not sun dried, the Preferred term in Materials is ‘fired clay’, with ‘baked clay’ a Non-Preferred Term, as it was frequently used historically. No Technique term is entered. N.B. In the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan, the Materials terms ‘mud’ and ‘clay’ have been used interchangeably for unfired objects such as bricks. figurines, and vessels.

Label: clinker
Scope note: Ash and partially fused residues from a cola fired furnace or fire.

Label: clove
Scope note: The term refers to a dried flower-bud used as a spice.

Label: coade stone
Scope note: Coade Stone is a stoneware manufactured in the 18th Century by Eleanor Coade.

Label: cocobolo wood
Scope note: The term has not been defined botanically and may be confused with coccoloba (ie. Coccoloba uvifera).

Label: coconut cuticle
Scope note: Skin of coconut frond-stem

Label: coke
Scope note: Coal with volatile constituents removed.

Label: copper alloy
Scope note: The term 'copper alloy' should be searched for full retrievals on objects made or bronze or brass. This is because bronze and brass have at times been used interchangeably in the old documentation, and copper alloy is the Broad Term of both. In addition, the public may refer to certain collections by their popular name, such as 'The Benin Bronzes' most of which are actually made of brass. The term 'copper alloy' is used in preference to 'billon' (in both Description and Materials) in records for Roman coins.

Label: coprolite
Scope note: The term refers to preserved or fossilised faeces (or excrement) of an animal or human.

Label: cork
Scope note: The term normally refers to bark from the cork oak tree, but it has also been given the Broad Term WOOD as it is not possible at present to determine the exact material in each individual record.

Label: cornelian
Scope note: Although 'carnelian' is the accepted term in mineralogical texts, the Preferred Term reflects accepted curatorial practice in the British Museum.

Label: cotton
Scope note: This term covers raw cotton as well as the textile.

Label: date
Scope note: The term refers to the fruit.

Label: diorite
Scope note: The terms DIORITE, GRANITE and SYENITE have been interchanged incorrectly.

Label: dog hair
Scope note: 'Dog' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild dogs as well as domesticated varieties.

Label: dog tissue
Scope note: 'Dog' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild dogs as well as domesticated varieties.

Label: dolerite
Scope note: Dolerite is of basaltic composition, but coarser grained than basalt because it is not extruded as lava from a volcano but intruded into the earth's crust at lesser or greater depths, and therefore cooled more slowly. It is described as an igneous rock.

Label: dung
Scope note: scats and pellets and droppings for excrement

Label: earthenware
Scope note: This term has been used interchangeably with TERRACOTTA and with POTTERY.

Label: egg
Scope note: Use for the whole egg, or the contents of the shell; for the eggshell alone, enter EGGSHELL.

Label: eggshell
Scope note: Use the term for the shell only: if the egg is included, enter EGG.

Label: egyptian blue
Scope note: The term refers to a synthetic calcium copper silicate pigment, with the mineral name cuprorivaite.

Label: elk tissue
Scope note: The North American variety is also called MOOSE.

Label: enamel
Scope note: The term 'enamel' has not been included as a Narrow term (NT) of 'glass' for practical reasons. Although technically enamel is glass with a lower melting temperature, the way enamel is applied and worked is quite different from glass, and users tend to search separately for objects made of either. See also 'enamelled' in the Techniques Thesaurus. N.B. The 'enamel' used in the Iron Age is not true enamel, which is fused by heat. It is heated opaque glass, which was pressed when molten into prepared metal fields or cells, and allowed to cool and harden. For these records, the term 'enamel' is entered in Description, the term 'enamelled' in Technique, but the Material entered is 'glass'. Records for ceramics painted in enamels do not have 'enamel' entered as a Material, but the term is recorded in Description.

Label: ethylene vinyl acetate
Scope note: flip-flop rubber

Label: fibre
Scope note: In this thesaurus, the term is restricted to vegetal fibre, and refers to fibrous material; it does not equate with the botanical definition of fibre. For animal fibre, use ANIMAL or its Narrow Terms. For fabric names, see under TEXTILE. The term FIBRE has been used interchangeably with LEAF in some areas of documentation.

Label: fig
Scope note: The term refers to the fruit.

Label: fired clay
Scope note: In this thesaurus, the term 'clay' refers to the raw material. If deliberately heated, whether in a fire or a kiln, etc. but not sun dried, the Preferred term in Materials is ‘fired clay’, with ‘baked clay’ a Non-Preferred Term, as it was frequently used historically. No Technique term is entered. In the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan: The Materials terms ‘mud’ and ‘clay’ have been used interchangeably for unfired objects such as bricks. figurines, and vessels. N.B. The term 'fired clay' has been used interchangeably with 'terracotta' and 'earthenware', but the term 'terracotta' is never used for vessels.

Label: flint
Scope note: For burnt flint, record burnt in the description, and in the Technique if the burning was deliberate.

Label: freshwater mussel shell
Scope note: Anadonta sp. If uncertain use the broader term mussel shell which acts for both salt and sea water varieties.

Label: frit
Scope note: The term refers to a ceramic composition that has been fused, quenched to form a glass, and granulated. Frits form an important part of the batches used in compounding enamels and glazes. Dodd, Dictionary of Ceramics (1967)

Label: fur
Scope note: The term refers to hair with skin.

Label: gabbro
Scope note: Gabbro is of basaltic composition, but coarser grained than basalt because it is not extruded as lava from a volcano but intruded into the earth's crust at lesser or greater depths, and therefore cooled more slowly. It is described as an igneous rock.

Label: giallo antico
Scope note: Yellow marble with red or pink spots or veins. One of the most used marbles in the whole of the Roman Empire, its quarry is located at Chemtou in Tunisia, ancient Numidia, hence its Latin name marmor numidicum.

Label: glass
Scope note: The term 'enamel' has not been included as a Narrow term (NT) of 'glass' for practical reasons. Although technically enamel is glass with a lower melting temperature, the way enamel is applied and worked is quite different from glass, and users tend to search for such objects independently. Mosaic glass is mostly Hellenistic in date and was created by chopping up rods and fusing them together in a mould of some sort.

Label: glazed composition
Scope note: The term is used for objects with a body made of finely powdered quartz grains fused together with small amounts of alkali and/or lime through partial heating. The bodies are usually colourless but natural impurities give them a brown or greyish tint. Colourants can also be added to give it an artificial colour. It can be modelled by hand, thrown or moulded, and hardens with firing. This material is used in the context of Islamic ceramics where it is described as stonepaste (or fritware). Glazed composition is related to glass, but glass is formed by completely fusing the ingredients in a liquid melted at high temperature. This material is also popularly called faience in the contexts of Ancient Egypt and Ancient Near East. However, this is a misnomer as these objects have no relationship to the glazed pottery vessels made in Faenza, from which the faience term derives. Other authors use the terms sintered quartz, glazed frit, frit, composition, Egyptian Blue, paste or (in the 19th century) even porcelain, although the last two terms are very inappropriate as they also describe imitation gems and a type of ceramic. Frit is technically a flux.

Label: gold
Scope note: The expression 'Pre-Columbian gold' is widely used to describe a range of materials: gold, and gold alloyed with other materials (e.g. copper, silver and platinum).

Label: gourd
Scope note: See also the Object Name GOURD.

Label: granite
Scope note: The terms DIORITE, GRANITE and SYENITE have been interchanged incorrectly.

Label: grass
Scope note: It is assumed that this term refers mainly to the leaf. The term 'grass does not refer to the classification term 'grass family' but to the non-specialist use of the term.

Label: gum-resin
Scope note: The dry exudate from a number of plants.

Label: gypsum-stucco
Scope note: The term refers to a stucco with gypsum.

Label: hemp
Scope note: The term refers to the fibre.

Label: hessian
Scope note: Hessian is a cloth traditionally made of a mixture of hemp and jute, but the composition may vary according to provenance.

Label: human remains
Scope note: Human remains are defined as whole bodies (or parts of bodies), bones, organs and tissue, as well as hair and nails. The way to retrieve all records for 'human remains' is to search for the term as a Material, rather than as an Object Name.

Label: hydrocarbon
Scope note: The Narrow Terms are defined as naturally occurring, although they may in some cases be processed.

Label: ichneumon skin
Scope note: The term refers to the Egyptian mongoose found in parts of Africa or Europe.

Label: indigo
Scope note: The term is only used for samples of the dye. See also INDIGO PLANT for the whole plant or unspecified parts.

Label: indigo plant
Scope note: Use INDIGO for the dye.

Label: invar
Scope note: An alloy of iron and nickel (FeNi36) invented in 1896 by Charles Édouard Guillaume for use in horology. Invar has an exceptionally low coefficient of thermal expansion and is therefore ideally suited for use in pendulums where temperature change can affect the timekeeping. The alloy has also been used for making watch balance springs.

Label: ironstone
Scope note: NB. not to be confused with earthenware (ironstone).

Label: istle
Scope note: Fibre obtained from Bromelia sylvestris and species of AGAVE used for cordage, nets etc.

Label: ivory
Scope note: IVORY and its Narrow Terms generally refer to worked material. See also TUSK and its Narrow Terms which generally refer to unworked material. The two terms have been used interchangeably in some records.

Label: karama fibre
Scope note: A type of bush vine found in Papua New Guinea.

Label: kelp gull feather
Scope note: Larus dominicanus feather.

Label: kiekie leaf
Scope note: A leaf used in Maori plaiting of mats and baskets.

Label: kurrajong bark fibre
Scope note: The term kurrajong is a local (common) name for the Brachychiton populneus tree (Malvaceae family), which in quite common in inland areas of New South Wales, Australia. Its leaves make good animal fodder, but its pale, spongy wood has limited use. The bark fibres are used for cordage and nets. Early settlers roasted and ground the seeds to make a drink.

Label: kurrajong wood
Scope note: The term kurrajong is a local (common) name for the Brachychiton populneus tree (Malvaceae family), which in quite common in inland areas of New South Wales, Australia. Its leaves make good animal fodder, but its pale, spongy wood has limited use. There is recorded Aboriginal use of the bark fibres for cordage and nets. Early settlers roasted and ground the seeds to make a drink.

Label: lac
Scope note: A resinous encrustation produced by insects, and used in the East as a scarlet dye. When treated, it is known as 'shellac'. The term lac may have been confused with LACQUER, and it may be necessary to search under both terms. For the Asian collections, objects described as 'lacquer' imply the technique of lacquer application on a substrate, and should have Technique 'lacquered'. Enter the Material 'lacquer (ie. tree resin)' or 'lac' (ie. insect secretion), depending on circumstance. Many objects from South Asia with 'lacquer' in Material may in fact be lacquered using lac. See also LACQUERED in the Techniques Thesaurus.

Label: lacquer
Scope note: For the Asian collections, objects described as 'lacquer' imply the technique of lacquer application on a substrate, and should have Technique 'lacquered'. Enter the Material 'lacquer (ie. tree resin)' or 'lac' (ie. insect secretion), depending on circumstance. Many objects from South Asia with 'lacquer' in Material may in fact be lacquered using lac. See also LACQUERED in the Techniques field. As a general rule, lacquered objects from the Middle East and South Asia are made using 'lac', while those from South East Asia and the far East are made using 'lacquer'.

Label: latten
Scope note: This is an archaic term for brass. It has been retained as a Preferred Term due to its use in the Medieval period, when it was sometimes regarded as a metal distinct from brass.

Label: leaf
Scope note: The term has been used interchangeably with FIBRE in some areas of the documentation.

Label: lime
Scope note: In this thesaurus, the term has several references, reflecting the documentation: - more specifically, a calcium oxide or calcium carbonate - in a more general sense, a white powdery material which has not been chemically identified and may or may not be 'lime' in the strict sense. - in the records for the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas, it usually refers to a substance taken with betel or coca or alternatively to a pigment, and usually made by burning leaves or coral.

Label: limestone
Scope note: See also records with 'calcium carbonate' in Materials and records with 'stalagmite' or 'stalactite' in Description.

Label: madder
Scope note: Use the term for the dye. See also MADDER PLANT for the whole plant or unspecified parts.

Label: madder plant
Scope note: Use MADDER for the dye.

Label: maire wood
Scope note: Nestegis cunninghamii, native of New Zealand.

Label: maireener shell
Scope note: Formerly known as Elenchus purpuratus and now known as Phasianotrochus irisodontes (2012). Found in South Australia, Victoria and Tasmania.

Label: malachite
Scope note: Cu2(CO3)(OH)2, Copper Carbonate Hydroxide. This is a deep green banded mineral.

Label: manna
Scope note: The term could refer to several materials.

Label: millboard
Scope note: The term refers to a kind of thick, stiff pasteboard, originally made of a pulp of old rope, sacking, paper, and other coarse matter milled or rolled with high pressure.

Label: mineral
Scope note: Minerals are generally defined in this thesaurus as naturally occurring chemical compounds. Minerals have a 'chemical' name (e.g. 'lead sulphide') and a 'mineral' name (e.g. 'galena') either of which may have been used in the documentation. It has been decided that the 'chemical' name will be the Broad Term. In order to broaden the scope of searches, certain terms are under both 'mineral' and 'stone'. N.B. - Stalagmite and stalagtite are composed of secondary minerals, mainly calcium carbonate, and are closely linked to the formation of limestone. - The term ‘crystal’ refers to a solid material that has its molecules or atoms or ions in a repeating, ordered (geometric) arrangement. Many different minerals and metals are in crystalline state or form. Although in the absence of a more specific identification, the Material could therefore be 'metal' as well as 'mineral', it is assumed that the latter is more likely, and so the term 'mineral' is entered as a Material.

Label: nenfro
Scope note: Nenfro is a highly localised name for a specific rock unit (e.g. Portland Limestone, Hertfordshire Puddingstone), but it is not a geological rock type.

Label: new zealand flax
Scope note: Commom form of Phormium: Phormium tenax (Maori name: harakeke). A group of tender perennials mainly grown for their colourful leaves. These plants, commonly known as New Zealand Flax, are natives of New Zealand. The word Phormium is derived from 'phormos', a basket, and refers to the use of the leaf fibre for basket making; this fibre is also used in the commercial manufacture of ropes and twine.

Label: nile oyster shell
Scope note: Etheria elliptica

Label: nullipore
Scope note: The term refers to any of various seaweeds able to secrete lime.

Label: nut
Scope note: The term encompasses the husk or shell.

Label: nut-putty
Scope note: Paste made from the fruit of the Atuna racemosa racemosa (Parinarium or Putty Nut) tree, used as an adhesive, filler and caulking.

Label: nutmeg
Scope note: The term refers to the seed.

Label: okra
Scope note: The term refers to the fruit.

Label: olivene
Scope note: Olivene is a term used to describe a variety of green garnet (typically from the Urals).

Label: olivine
Scope note: Olivine refers to a group of minerals which includes chrysolite (sometimes used to refer to gem quality olivine, which is known also as peridot).

Label: orchid
Scope note: The term refers to the flower.

Label: osier stem
Scope note: A species of willow much used in basket-work.

Label: osmund
Scope note: Osmund is a form of wrought iron.

Label: ostrich egg
Scope note: Use for the whole egg; for the shell, use OSTRICH EGGSHELL.

Label: ovulum ovum shell
Scope note: Also known as the Egg Shell, but in fact a mollusc shell.

Label: palladium
Scope note: A white metal, resistant to tarnishing. A member of the platinum family of metals.

Label: pandanus fibre
Scope note: There are over 600 species in the Pandanus genus, but one of the most commonly used species, and most applicable to BM material, is Pandanus tectorius. Some taxonomists have separated the family Pandanaceae (screw-pine) including the Pandanus species from the Palmae; others see Pandanaceae as part of the extended family of Palmae.

Label: pandanus fruit
Scope note: There are over 600 species in the Pandanus genus, but one of the most commonly used species, and most applicable to BM material, is Pandanus tectorius. Some taxonomists have separated the family Pandanaceae (screw-pine) including the Pandanus species from the Palmae; others see Pandanaceae as part of the extended family of Palmae.

Label: pandanus leaf
Scope note: There are over 600 species in the Pandanus genus, but one of the most commonly used species, and most applicable to BM material, is Pandanus tectorius. Some taxonomists have separated the family Pandanaceae (screw-pine) including the Pandanus species from the Palmae; others see Pandanaceae as part of the extended family of Palmae.

Label: pandanus root
Scope note: There are over 600 species in the Pandanus genus, but one of the most commonly used species, and most applicable to BM material, is Pandanus tectorius. Some taxonomists have separated the family Pandanaceae (screw-pine) including the Pandanus species from the Palmae; others see Pandanaceae as part of the extended family of Palmae.

Label: pandanus seed
Scope note: There are over 600 species in the Pandanus genus, but one of the most commonly used species, and most applicable to BM material, is Pandanus tectorius. Some taxonomists have separated the family Pandanaceae (screw-pine) including the Pandanus species from the Palmae; others see Pandanaceae as part of the extended family of Palmae.

Label: pandanus wood
Scope note: There are over 600 species in the Pandanus genus, but one of the most commonly used species, and most applicable to BM material, is Pandanus tectorius. Some taxonomists have separated the family Pandanaceae (screw-pine) including the Pandanus species from the Palmae; others see Pandanaceae as part of the extended family of Palmae. C.R. Cartwright (25/04/2008)

Label: papyrus
Scope note: A substance prepared from the stem of the papyrus plant. The term is also entered in the Object Name field. For the material not treated in this specific way see PAPYRUS STEM.

Label: paradise shelduck feather
Scope note: Tadorna variegata feather.

Label: parchment
Scope note: If the the animal type is also known, enter as an additonal entry, e.g. buffalo skin.

Label: pavonazzetto
Scope note: White marble with dark blue, dark red or purple veining (its Italian name alluding to the similarity of the colours of a peacock). Also called Phrygian marble, after the region in Turkey that it comes from, its quarry is located near the town of Afyon.

Label: pearlshell
Scope note: If the specific type is known, enter both. e.g. pearlshell and nautilus shell.

Label: peridot
Scope note: Olivine refers to a group of minerals which includes chrysolite (sometimes used to refer to gem quality olivine, which is known also as peridot).

Label: pig bone
Scope note: 'Pig' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild pigs as well as domesticated varieties.

Label: pig hair
Scope note: 'Pig' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild pigs as well as domesticated varieties.

Label: pig skin
Scope note: 'Pig' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild pigs as well as domesticated varieties.

Label: pig tissue
Scope note: 'Pig' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild pigs as well as domesticated varieties.

Label: pig tooth
Scope note: 'Pig' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild pigs as well as domesticated varieties.

Label: pig tusk
Scope note: 'Pig' terms are used as Broad Terms covering wild pigs as well as domesticated varieties.

Label: pine bark fibre
Scope note: It is not clear which precise material this term refers to.

Label: pitchstone
Scope note: This is an acceptable term for some forms of volcanic glass in Scottish Neolithic.

Label: pituri leaf
Scope note: Leaf of an Australian shrub, used as a narcotic.

Label: plancheite
Scope note: Plancheite is a copper silicate mineral.

Label: plant specimen
Scope note: The Narrow Terms of PLANT SPECIMEN may refer to entire named specimens, or to those for which the documentation did not specify a constituent. The term itself can also be entered in the record as a material referring simply to an unidentified plant.

Label: plumbago
Scope note: The term used to refer to a mixture of graphite and clay, mainly used for making crucibles.

Label: polyester fibre
Scope note: The term refers to a man-made fibre consisting of polyester. It should be used for textiles; in other contexts use polyester or polystyrene.

Label: pomegranate
Scope note: The term refers to the fruit.

Label: portasanta
Scope note: Brecciated marble, with yellow, orange, red and dark red spots and veins, on either a pink or a dark red background. Called marmor chium in Roman times, after the island Chios that it comes from, it medieval Italian name alludes to the door’s of St Peter’s church in Rome, whose doors are made of this marble.

Label: potash
Scope note: In this thesaurus, the term has two references, reflecting the documentation: - another name for a potassium compound - in a more traditional sense as the ash from burning wood (?) in a pot.

Label: pottery
Scope note: This term has been used interchangeably with EARTHENWARE and with TERRACOTTA. For the Department of Prehistory and Europe, enter EARTHENWARE instead of POTTERY for post-Medieval collections.

Label: prickly pear
Scope note: The term refers to the fruit.

Label: proto-stoneware
Scope note: This is technically a boundary area between earthenware and stoneware.

Label: puddingstone
Scope note: In the UK, the term refers to a specific rock type.

Label: pukeko bone
Scope note: Porphyrio porphyrio melanotus bone.

Label: pukeko claw
Scope note: Porphyrio porphyrio melanotus.

Label: pukeko tissue
Scope note: Porphyrio porphyrio melanotus tissue.

Label: pumpkin
Scope note: The term refers to the fruit.

Label: putty nut
Scope note: Atuna racemosa subsp. racemosa Chrysobalanaceae family

Label: pvc
Scope note: polyvinylchloride

Label: pyrophyllite
Scope note: Mineral consisting of aluminium silicate

Label: rattan
Scope note: The term usually refers to the fibres and stems of a group of climbing palms. Its use has been restricted to the stems.

Label: rattlesnake tissue
Scope note: Rattlesnake tissue includes the snake's rattle, which consists of hollow modified scales from the tip of the snake's tail. When the rattlesnake sheds its skin, a new segment is added to the rattle. After a period of time e.g,. when the rattle has about 7 segments, it can break off and, at this point, might be collected. Or the rattlesnake might be killed (e.g. for food) and its rattle detached deliberately for use as a ritual / musical object.

Label: red ivory tree wood
Scope note: African.

Label: red-billed gull feather
Scope note: Larus novaehollandiae scopulinus feather.

Label: reed
Scope note: Some reeds are in the Poaceae family, some are not and belong to other families i.e. Reed is a generic botanical term used to describe numerous tall, grass-like plants of wet places. They are all members of the order Poales and include: In the Poaceae (grass) family Common reed, Phragmites australis Giant reed, Arundo donax Burma reed, Neyraudia reynaudiana Reed Canary-grass , Phalaris arundinacea Reed sweet-grass, Glyceria maxima Small-reed, Calamagrostis species In the Cyperaceae (sedge) family Paper reed or papyrus, Cyperus papyrus In the Sparganiaceae family Bur-reed, Sparganium species In the Typhaceae family Reed-mace , Typha species, also called bulrush or cattail In the Restionaceae family Cape Thatching Reed, Chrondopetalum tectorum, a restio from South Africa. Thatching Reed, Thamnochortus insignis, a restio from South Africa.

Label: rhizome
Scope note: A horizontally creeping underground stem which bears roots and leaves and usually persists from season to season.

Label: rubber
Scope note: The term refers to both natural rubber and synthetic rubber.

Label: safflower
Scope note: The term refers to the flower.

Label: same
Scope note: The term refers to shark skin, ray skin, or similar material wrapped around the wooden core of the hilt (tsuka) and under the cord (tsuka ito) in Japanese swords.

Label: sap
Scope note: Also search under GUM and RESIN

Label: scapolite
Scope note: Calcium Sodium Aluminum Silicate Carbonate Chloride Sulfate.

Label: sedge
Scope note: It is assumed that this term refers mainly to the leaf.

Label: serpentino
Scope note: Igneous rock with small, light green, rectangular specks within a dark green background. Extremely popular in Roman times, generally called ‘green porphyry’, and quarried near Sparta in Greece.

Label: shagreen
Scope note: In this thesaurus, the term only refers to untanned leather prepared from the skin of the shark.

Label: sheepskin
Scope note: This refers to the sheep's skin with the wool on. Use SHEEP SKIN when depilated.

Label: shell
Scope note: The term (which in this thesaurus includes CUTTLEFISH BONE) should not be confused with EGGSHELL. Mollusc shell may be composed (wholly or in part) of calcite. But also can be composed (wholly or in part) of aragonite and sometimes both together e.g. mussels, with an outer calcite shell and inner aragonite layer (bimineralic shells).

Label: silk
Scope note: Satin is a weave structure and so is included, like 'velvet', in the Techniques rather than Materials thesaurus. Both terms, however, are commonly used to describe what an object is made of (or a support). Although in the case of satin, the lustrous effect is often made using silk thread, other fibres can also be used.

Label: silver
Scope note: The term silver-gilt refers to a base of silver to which a layer of gilding has been applied. The Materials entered are 'silver' and 'gold' and the Technique 'gilded'. For Greek and Roman coins historically referred to as billon or base silver, enter 'base silver' in Description, 'silver' in Materials and 'base' in Materials Comment. For Medieval coins, enter 'billon' in both Description and Materials. For any other objects made of base silver, enter 'base silver' in Description and 'silver' in Materials. .

Label: silver alloy
Scope note: The term hacksilver is an Object Name. For Greek coins described as made of 'base silver' , the term 'base silver' is entered in Description, and 'silver alloy' in Materials.

Label: silver-gilt
Scope note: The term silver-gilt refers to a base of silver to which a layer of gold has been applied. The Technique entered is gilded.

Label: sinew
Scope note: Where the sinew occurs with other types of tissue, use TISSUE or one of its Narrow Terms.

Label: skin
Scope note: The term should not be used for skin with hair. See also FUR.

Label: solder
Scope note: Molten mixture of lead and tin.

Label: sparrow feather
Scope note: Passer domesticus domesticus feather.

Label: stone
Scope note: The term refers to a combination of minerals, but may have been used as a substitute for MINERAL or its Narrow Terms in the documentation. In order to broaden the scope of searches, certain terms are under both 'mineral' and 'stone'. Searches on 'stone' as a Broad Term will include records for objects made of shell because of their calcium carbonate content.

Label: stonepaste
Scope note: The term stonepaste is used in the contex of Islamic ceramics from about 12thC onwards. It describes an artificial ceramic body made from ground quartz with small additions of clay and ground glaze-mixture. The term fritware is also used for this material.

Label: stucco
Scope note: The term 'stucco' is used here in a general sense as it can have various meanings, but traditionally refers to a wall coating or render. However, the term also refers to sculptural and artistic use of the material for decoration and figurative representations. Stucco can be of various compositions: it is usually an aggregate of lime and sand, but may be of other compositions. The composition should be specified where known, e.g. lime-stucco or gypsum-stucco, etc. See also the Technique term 'stuccoed'.

Label: sugilite
Scope note: Also known as lavulite from South Africa, increasingly used in Southwestern American jewellery.

Label: swamp harrier feather
Scope note: Circus approximans feather.

Label: sycamore wood
Scope note: Synonymous with the 'maple' or Acer pseudoplatanus from the family Aceraceae (For objects from Egypt and elsewhere within the Near and Middle East use 'sycomore fig', unless conclusive evidence to the contrary exists).

Label: sycomore fig wood
Scope note: Ficus sycomorus from the family Moraceae. Found in Egypt and elsewhere in the Near and Middle East (previously confused with the 'sycamore', and often recorded as being such, in older documentary sources).

Label: syenite
Scope note: The terms DIORITE, GRANITE and SYENITE have been interchanged incorrectly.

Label: synthetic
Scope note: Use this term - in the absence of a more specific material - for synthetic wool, synthetic caribou sinew, etc. The category includes materials which are, strictly speaking, semi-synthetics.

Label: synthetic fibre
Scope note: The term should be used for textiles; in other contexts use synthetic or its Narrow Terms.

Label: synthetic latex
Scope note: The term refers to any dispersion in water of particles of a polymer (originally synthetic rubber) that is formed in a polymerization process, such as is used as a binder in paints or for coating paper and leather.

Label: taffeta
Scope note: The term 'taffeta' was applied at different times to different fabrics.

Label: te ngea wood
Scope note: 'Te ngea' (Pemphis acidula) is a saltbush with very hard wood, and grows very close to the water, mainly on the lagoon shore.

Label: terracotta
Scope note: This term has been used interchangeably with 'fired clay' and 'earthenware'. The term 'terracootta' is never used for vessels.

Label: textile
Scope note: The term is defined in this thesaurus as 'cloth', whether woven, beaten, knitted or otherwise manufactured. If an object is regarded as a textile, but the material term already occurs in this thesaurus under another Broad Term, enter 'textile' in the record as an additional keyword. Velvet is a technique rather than a textile - please enter 'velvet' into technique and 'textile' in material. Where possible, use the type of textile that has been velveted, eg silk or cotton. Felt and kesi refer to the finished product, and are neither materials nor techniques (use tapestry for kesi and felted for felt). See also FIBRE and its Narrow Terms.

Label: thayo
Scope note: Putty created from sap mixed with ash or sawdust, which can then be sculpted.

Label: tortoise carapace
Scope note: This refers to the whole shell or exoskeleton. Use TORTOISE-SHELL for decorative pieces.

Label: tortoise-shell
Scope note: In The Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas records, the term refers to decorative pieces; for the entire shell or exoskeleton, use TORTOISE CARAPACE.

Label: travertine
Scope note: The suggestion by some authorities to use the term 'travertine' for Egyptian alabaster (ie. calcite) is not generally accepted.

Label: tree latex
Scope note: The term refers to a milky liquid found in many plants in special vessels called latex tubes or lacticifers. This latex can be used commercially, e.g. Hevea brasiliensis used to produce rubber.

Label: tufa
Scope note: Tufa is a terrestrial rock formed by the crystallising of carbonate minerals, mainly calcite, from water. The terms 'tuff' and 'tufa' have been confused in some areas of the documentation; see also under 'tuff'.

Label: tuff
Scope note: Tuff is a type of volcanic rock, and is formed from ash that is ejected from certain types of volcano during eruptions. The ash forms beds, which when consolidated (solidified) are called ‘tuff’. Depending on the comparative amounts of ash/volcanic glass/rock fragments in the tuff it is called either crystal-, vitreous-, or lithic-tuff. Tuffs can be formed from either ash-fall (e.g. Mount Pinatubo)or ash-flow (e.g. Vesuvius-Pompeii) eruptions. Tuffs are very fine grained rocks (grains usually no bigger than 2mm in diameter).

Label: turmeric
Scope note: The term is assumed to refer to the spice or dye, obtained from the rhizome. See also TURMERIC PLANT.

Label: turtle-shell
Scope note: In the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas records, the term refers to decorative pieces. Use TURTLE CARAPACE for the whole shell or exoskeleton.

Label: tusk
Scope note: TUSK and its Narrow Terms generally refer to unworked material, whereas IVORY and its Narrow Terms generally refer to worked material. The two terms have been used interchangeably in some records.

Label: umimatsu
Scope note: The term refers to fossilized wood.

Label: varnish
Scope note: See also VARNISHED in the Techniques Thesaurus.

Label: vegetal fat
Scope note: To cover such terms as Shea butter.

Label: velveteen
Scope note: The term applies to a fabric having the appearance or surface of velvet, but made from cotton or synthetic yarn in place of silk. The specific material should also be entered where known.

Label: virenium
Scope note: Virenium is a patented silver-coloured base metal alloy in the Nickel Silver family, often used for commemorative coins and medals. Composed largely of copper, with nickel, zinc and other constituents. Intended to have the look and stability of precious metal. Used in high denomination coinage since 1978. Trademark of Pobjoy Mint Ltd.

Label: volcanic stone
Scope note: The term is used here to cover all geological materials, including ash and lava, formed through external volcanic processes.

Label: walnut
Scope note: The term refers to the nut.

Label: water chestnut
Scope note: check

Label: whalebone
Scope note: See also ivory - although not strictly the same material as whalebone/baleen, may be of interest.

Label: white metal
Scope note: This term could refer to PEWTER, TIN, SILVER ALLOY, etc.

Label: white paste
Scope note: A term used for a white material, usually of shell, but sometimes imitated in bone or composition, and used for decorative bosses and discs on Anglo-Saxon and Dark Age jewellery.

Label: willow
Scope note: The term refers to the wood.

Label: wool
Scope note: Although felt may not be made entirely of wool, wool is a major constituent. Any additional materials are entered where known.

Label: yew
Scope note: The term refers to the wood.
